trustfund:
TF030371-DANISH CTF FY03 - SUB-SAHARAN AFRICA,TF052414-PHRD-SIERRA
            LEONE:INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF096539-GRSF: Sierra Leone Road Safety
            Management Capacity Review
theme: Infrastructure services for private sector development,State-owned enterprise restructuring and privatization,Rural services and infrastructure,Regulation and competition policy

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome rating of the
            Infrastructure Development Project for Sierra Leone was
            judged to be moderately satisfactory.  The Bank and borrower
            performance ratings were moderately satisfactory.  The risk
            to development outcome was high.  Several lessons were
            learned.  Institutional reform takes time and the Bank
            should continue to be patient with institutions undergoing
            reform process, especially fragile states like Sierra Leone.
            Institutional reform consists of change in attitude and
            always meets with resistance. It took considerable efforts
            to get the Bills necessary to create the new institutions.
            Following parliaments approval, the low capacity in the
            country made it difficult to operationalize the new
            agencies. The monitoring and evaluation (M&E) capacity
            in the implementing agencies is key to adequate monitoring
            of results. The capacity to collect and monitor project
            performance indicator was weak at the Implementation
            Agencies. Building capacity for M&E should start at
            project preparation. Furthermore, the baseline data should
            be mandatory for collection in the first year of project
            implementation.  The procurement process remained a
            significant challenge and delayed project implementation.
            Preparing Terms of Reference, bidding documents, evaluating
            and awarding contracts are a specific skills set. The
            development of such skilled manpower requires special
            attention to ensure projects are completed on time. In a
            post-crisis political-economic environment, Governments may
            find it necessary to retreat on policy reforms where
            commitments were made. Such retreats may be vital to
            securing stability and to advance when the political economy
            permits. In such conditions the Bank may need to re-consider
            the political economic climate which determines the policies
            to advance at any given time in its relationship with the
            Government.   Quality at Entry (QEA) is an important step
            ensuring project implementation readiness. The civil works
            bidding documents at were not ready at project appraisal.
            Considerable time was lost in completing the design of the
            civil works. This could have been identified at QEA and the
            delay could have been averted.
